prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(4-3) at z=2.18 or z=2.43
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the CO(4-3) line from star-forming cluster galaxies at z~2.18 - 2.43

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
In this central pointing, our goal - as discussed in the science justification, is to measure the CO(4-3) line for galaxies in the structure with star formation rates as low as ~30Msun/yr (Chabrier). Probing the CO(4-3) line (falling in band 4 for our target's redshift) offers the significant advantage of spanning, with a single frequency setting, the full spectral range possibly associated with both redshift spikes in the spectroscopic redshift distribution. Although, based on the currently available spectroscopy, the z=2.18 spike appears much more obviously connected with the projected galaxy overdensity, these observations give us the opportunity to measure redshifts for the target sample in an unbiased way, whichever the redshift peak they might belong to. In the following we quote numbers for the most likely redshift of z~2.18, but adjusted SNR and exposure times so to have an adequate measurement also for sources at z~2.43.
This SFR limit of 30 Msun/yr corresponds to an IR luminosity L_IR ~3e+11 Lsun. Based on the observed correlation between L'_CO and L_IR up to high redshift as measured in Sargent et al. 2013, and assuming a line FWHM of ~350km/s, and detailed measurements of the CO SLED of 4 BzK galaxies detected up to CO(5-4) (Daddi et al., in prep.), we estimate our target CO(4-3) line flux as ~ 0.41mJy. We require an rms of ~0.09mJy in order to obtain a >4sigma detection for all our targets.
According to the ALMA OT sensitivity calculator, with standard calibrations and wheather conditions, and 34 antennas, the required sensitivity for these observations may be reached with a total exposure time on source of ~1.3h, or ~2.7h including time on calibrators and overheads. For these spectral line observations we will use FDM. We ask for 4 1875Mhz basebands to probe the full velocity sructure around both redshift peaks, with sufficient resolution to ensure accurate line measurements. Given the angular size of our targets, we are typically interested in angular scales not larger than 2-3", and being this a detection experiment, we do not ask for particularly high angular resolution. Therefore, any configuration giving an angular resolution of order ~0.5-1" (e.g. C34-3 to C34-6 for band 4) will be appropriate for our purposes.

With this science goal, we aim at measuring 350GHz continuum fluxes to a depth matching the SFR level of the CO(4-3) line observations. Due to the HPBW of these band 7 observations, we need to observe targets individually. We have 13 targets down to a flux density corresponding to SFR~80 Msun/yr, and 4 targets in the central band 4 pointing down to SFR ~30 Msun/yr. The two SFR limits of 30 and 80 Msun/yr, correspond to IR luminosities of L_IR~3.e+11 and 8.e+11 Lsun. We estimate the observed continuum flux density at 350GHz based on far-IR templates. In order to avoid the overestimation from the "main-sequence template" (Elbaz et al. 2011), we use the appropriate SED for a main-sequence galaxy at the cluster redshift from the 2SFM modeling of Bethermin et al. 2012, based on the Magdis et al. (2012) templates. This gives an expected 350GHz flux density for our targets of ~0.31 and 0.82mJy for the SFR limits of 30 and 80 Msun/yr, respectively.
According to the ALMA OT sensitivity calculator, with standard calibrations and wheather conditions, a total bandwidth of 7.5GHz and 34 antennas, we can reach a >4sigma detection for all our targets in ~2' (10') on source for the 80Msun/yr (30Msun/yr) SFR limit, respectively. Also in this case, as for the CO(4-3) observations, while we quote numbers for the most likely redshift of z=2.18, we adjust SNR request to ensure adequate detection of the sources also if they were at z=2.43).
In order to minimise overheads, we include in this science goal both the brighter SFR>80 Msun/yr targets, and the fainter SFR>30Msun/yr ones, by replicating the pointing on the fainter targets 5 times.
Including all overheads, these observations will require ~1.6 hours. For these continuum observations we will use TDM, and dual polarization.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(4-3) at z=2.18 or z=2.43 for bright targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations of the CO(4-3) line from star-forming cluster galaxies at z~2.18 or 2.43, 10 pointings.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
WIth this science goal we target massive galaxies with SFR>80Msun/yr (Chabrier). 10 pointings are used to observe all such candidate cluster members within one Mpc of the central passive overdensity. As discussed in the scence justification, we aim at measuring the CO(4-3) line. Probing the CO(4-3) line (falling in band 4 for our target's redshift) offers the significant advantage of spanning, with a single frequency setting, the full spectral range possibly associated with both redshift spikes in the spectroscopic redshift distribution. Although, based on the currently available spectroscopy, the z=2.18 spike appears much more obviously connected with the projected galaxy overdensity, these observations give us the opportunity to measure redshifts for the target sample in an unbiased way, whichever the redshift peak they might belong to. In the following we quote numbers for the most likely redshift of z~2.18, but adjusted SNR and exposure times so to have an adequate measurement also for sources at z~2.43.
The SFR limit of 80 Msun/yr corresponds to an IR luminosity L_IR ~8e+11 Lsun. Based on the observed correlation between L'_CO and L_IR up to high redshift as measured in Sargent et al. 2013, and assuming a line FWHM of ~350km/s, and detailed measurements of the CO SLED of 4 BzK galaxies detected up to CO(5-4) (Daddi et al., in prep.), we estimate our target CO(4-3) line flux as ~ 0.93mJy. We require an rms of ~0.21mJy in order to obtain a >4sigma detection for all our targets.
According to the ALMA OT sensitivity calculator, with standard calibrations and wheather conditions, and 34 antennas, the required sensitivity for these observations may be reached with an exposure time of ~14' per pointing, or ~2.3h for all 10 pointings, for a total time of ~4.7h including calibrators and overheads. For these spectral line observations we will use FDM. We ask for 4 1875Mhz basebands to probe the full velocity sructure around both redshift peaks, with sufficient resolution to ensure accurate line measurements. Given the angular size of our targets, we are typically interested in angular scales not larger than 2-3", and being this a detection experiment, we do not ask for particularly high angular resolution. Therefore, any configuration giving an angular resolution of order ~0.5-1" (e.g. C34-3 to C34-6 for band 4) will be appropriate for our purposes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA observations in the field of a very distant cluster progenitor at z~2.2. We identified this structure as an overdensity of massive passive galaxies with consistent photometric redshifts z~2.3, on the physical scale of a typical cluster core. The overdensity is confirmed also for the whole galaxy population, and based on independent photo-z estimates. Available optical and NIR spectroscopy suggests that the galaxy overdensity seems indeed to be likely associated with a redshift spike at z~2.2. This structure is thus a very convincing candidate of cluster progenitor environment, already characterised by a small core population of quiescent galaxies at an epoch when passive galaxies are still remarkably rare. On the other hand, as in many z>1.5 structures, there is evidence for a substantial number of massive candidate cluster members which are instead actively star forming. This proposal targets such massive star-forming galaxies, to investigate the diverse massive galaxy populations in early dense environments, and at the same ultimately confirm the nature of this structure and its redshift.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
